title: AuPair: Golden Example Pairs for Code Repair
author: Aditi Mavalankar (Google DeepMind), Hassan Mansoor (Google DeepMind), Zita Marinho (Google DeepMind), Masha Samsikova (Google DeepMind), Tom Schaul (Google DeepMind), ...
relevance_why: The method enhances the code repair process, which can be advantageous for improving automated audio coding frameworks and perhaps facilitate debugging in audio-related machine learning tasks.
background: This research focuses on improving the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) in code repair by utilizing examples of incorrect guesses and their respective fixes to produce better solutions.
contribution: AuPair introduces an inference-time algorithm that constructs a golden set of code repair examples, boosting performance significantly when used as in-context examples.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like best-of- and self-repair improve responses through repetitive sampling or intermediate feedback but may lack diversity.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work synthesizes and selects complementary example pairs (AuPairs) to enhance the self-repair capability of LLMs without repetitive querying.

key_innovation: AuPair leverages a submodular selection process to produce diverse and useful fixes, maximizing performance gains across different coding problems.
real_world_impact: The method potentially streamlines code repair tasks across various domains, which could be adapted to automated debugging in audio processing systems.
limitations: No explicit limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.AuPair: **AuPair** refers to a pair of an initial flawed code guess and a corresponding correct fix, specifically curated to enhance the self-repair capabilities of language models in coding tasks.
